chapter.title: The &cloud; Architecture
chapter.para: &productname; is a cloud infrastructure solution that can easily be deployed and managed. It offers a cloud management solution that helps organizations to centralize virtual machine deployment. &productname; &productnumber; provides the following features:

listitem.para: Open source software that is based on the &ostack; &latest_ostack; release.
Centralized resource tracking providing insight into activities and capacity of the cloud infrastructure for optimized automated deployment of services.
A self-service portal enabling end users to configure and deploy services as necessary, also offering the ability to track resource consumption (&o_dash;).
An image repository from which standardized, pre-configured virtual machines can be published (&o_img;).
Automated installation processes via &crow; utilizing pre-defined scripts for configuring and deploying the &contrnode;(s) as well as Compute and &stornode;s.
Multi-tenant, role-based provisioning and access control for multiple departments and users within your organization.
APIs enabling the integration of third-party software, such as identity management and billing solutions.

chapter.para: &productname; is based on &sls;, &ostack;, &crow;, and &chef;. &sls; is used as the underlying operating system for all cloud infrastructure machines (also called nodes), whereas &ostack;, the cloud management layer, works as the Cloud Operating System. &crow; and &chef; are used to automatically deploy and manage the &ostack; nodes from a central &admserv;.
&productname; is deployed to four different types of machines:

listitem.para: one &admserv; for node deployment and management
one or more &contrnode;s hosting the cloud management services
several &compnode;s on which the &vmguest;s are started
several &stornode;s for block and object storage

sect1.title: The &admserv;
sect1.para: The &admserv; provides all services needed to manage and deploy all other nodes in the cloud. Most of these services are provided by the &crow; tool that automates in conjunction with &chef; all the required installation and configuration tasks. Among the services provided by the server are DHCP, DNS, NTP, PXE, TFTP.

The &admserv; also hosts the software repositories for &sls; and &productname;, since they are needed for node deployment. Optionally (if no other sources for the software repositories are available) it can also host the &smtool; (⪪), providing up-to-date repositories with updates and patches for all nodes.

sect1.title: The &contrnode;(s)
sect1.para: The &contrnode;(s) hosts all &ostack; services needed to orchestrate virtual machines deployed on the &compnode;s in the &cloud;. &ostack; on &cloud; uses a &postgres; database, which is also hosted on the &contrnode;(s). The following &ostack; components and dependencies run on the &contrnode;(s):

listitem.para: &postgres; database
&img; (&o_img;) for managing virtual images
&ident; (&o_ident;), providing authentication and authorization for all &ostack; services
&netw; (&o_netw;), providing networking as a service between interface devices managed by other &ostack; services
&blockstore; (&o_blockstore;), providing block storage
&ostack; ‐ (&o_dash;), providing the ‐, which is a user Web interface for the &ostack; services
∁ (&o_comp;) management (Nova controller) including API and scheduler
Message broker (RabbitMQ)
&o_objstore; proxy server plus dispersion tools. &o_objstore; provides object storage.
&o_objstore; Ring
&ceph; master cluster monitor

sect1.para: Being a central point in the &cloud; architecture that runs a lot of services, a single &contrnode; can quickly become a performance bottleneck, especially in large &cloud; deployments. It is possible to distribute the services listed above on more than one &contrnode;, up to a setup where each service runs on its own node.

Deploying &netw; (&o_netw;) on a distinct node is a general recommendation for production clouds. It will separate the network management and most of the network traffic and will also allow to define a distinct network mode for this node (see for details).

Hosting &ident; (&o_ident;) on a distinct node enables you to separate authentication and authorization services from other cloud services for security reasons. Another good candidate to be hosted on a separate node is &blockstore; (&o_blockstore;, particularly the cinder-volume role) when using local disks for storage. Deploying it on one or more separate node enables you to equip the node with storage and network hardware best suiting the service.

note.title: Moving Services in an Existing Setup
note.para: In case you plan to move a service in an already deployed &cloud; from one &contrnode; to another, it is strongly recommended to shut down or save all &vmguest;s before doing so (and restart them after having successfully re-deployed the services). Moving services also requires to stop them manually on the original &contrnode;.

sect1.title: The &compnode;s
sect1.para: The &compnode;s are the pool of machines on which the &vmguest;s are running. These machines need to be equipped with a sufficient number of CPUs and enough RAM to start several &vmguest;s. They also need to provide sufficient hard disk space, see for details. The &contrnode; effectively distributes &vmguest;s within the pool of &compnode;s and provides the necessary network resources. The &ostack; service ∁ (Nova) runs on the &compnode;s and provides means for setting up, starting, and stopping virtual machines.

&productname; supports several hypervisors such as Hyper-V, &kvm;, QEMU, VMware vSphere or &xen;. Each image that can be started with an &vmguest; is bound to one hypervisor. Each &compnode; can only run one hypervisor at a time. You can choose which hypervisor to run on which &compnode; when deploying the Nova &barcl;.

sect1.title: The &stornode;s
sect1.para: The &stornode;s are the pool of machines providing object storage. &cloud; offers two different types of storage: object and block storage. Object storage is provided by the &ostack; &swift; component, while block storage is provided by &ceph;. Deploying &swift; is optional, &ceph; is available as a technology preview.

sect1.title: &ha; Setup
sect1.para: A failure of some crucial components in &productname; can lead to system downtime and/or data loss. To prevent this, a maintenance update for &productname; &productnumber; allows you to make all functions provided by the &contrnode;(s) highly available. During cloud deployment, you can choose to apply certain roles to an &ha; (HA) cluster (consisting of several cluster nodes) instead of applying them to individual cloud nodes.

This includes especially the roles for data, services, and network running on the &contrnode;(s). With an &hasetup;, the cloud will continue to operate in case of an outage of one or more &contrnode;s. This also includes the ability to start and stop VMs on the &compnode;, without loss of state.

For all HA-enabled roles, the respective functions are automatically handled by the clustering software &sle; &hasi;. The &hasi; uses the Pacemaker cluster stack with Pacemaker as cluster resource manager and &corosync;/&ais; as messaging/infrastructure layer.

You can view the cluster status and configuration
with the cluster management tools &haweb; (&hawk;), &hbgui;, or the crm shell. Note however, that these tools provide a read-only view, because all of the clustering configuration is done automatically via &crow; and &chef;—you do not need to configure anything manually. When doing any manual changes with the cluster management tools you run the risk of breaking the cluster or have the changes reverted by the next run of &chef; anyway.

A failure of the &ostack; infra-structure services (running on the &contrnode;) is the most crucial point of failure that can cause downtimes within the cloud.
